level.text: In rejecting goods, a lessee's failure to state a particular defect that is ascertainable by reasonable inspection precludes the lessee from relying on the defect to justify rejection or to establish default:
If, stated seasonably, the lessor or the supplier could have cured it (§ 28:2A-513); or
Between merchants if the lessor or the supplier after rejection has made a request in writing for a full and final written statement of all defects on which the lessee proposes to rely.
A lessee's failure to reserve rights when paying rent or other consideration against documents precludes recovery of the payment for defects apparent on the face of the documents.

level.heading: UNIFORM COMMERCIAL CODE COMMENT
level.text: Changes: Revised to reflect leasing practices and terminology.

Purposes: The principles applicable to the commercial practice of payment against documents (subsection 2) are explained in official comment 4 to Section 2-605, the statutory analogue to this section.

level.heading: Legislative History of Laws
level.text: For legislative history of D.C. Law 9-128, see Historical and Statutory Notes following § 28:2A-101.
